clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Intensive Training on Reocvery of Fingers Dexterity Following Stroke
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Intensive Training on Recovery of Fingers Dexterity Following Stroke: Behavioral, Physiological and Anatomical Predictors

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators aim to test whether intensive training of finger individuation during the sensitive window of the subacute phases can lead to a clinically-meaningful recovery of dexterous movement in stroke patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Fugl-Meyer Assessment Score for Upper Extremity at the immediate post-intervention time
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-3 days post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: A Likert-scale that quantifies movement quality, sensation, range of motion and pain in the upper limb following stroke. Range: 0 - 66. Higher values correlate with better motor control.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Fugl-Meyer Assessment Score for Upper Extermity at 1-month post-intervention
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1 month post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: A Likert-scale that quantifies movement quality, sensation, range of motion and pain in the upper limb following stroke. Range: 0 - 66. Higher values correlate with better motor control.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Fugl-Meyer Assessment Score for Upper Extermity at 3-months post-intervention
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 3 months post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: A Likert-scale that quantifies movement quality, sensation, range of motion and pain in the upper limb following stroke. Range: 0 - 66. Higher values correlate with better motor control.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Individuation Index at the immediate post-intervention time
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-3 days post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: The relationship between forces (in Newton) in the active vs. passive fingers during a set of isolated finger movements. Higher numbers correlate with better finger-joint individuation, thus better dexterity.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Individuation Index at 1-month post-intervention
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-month post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: The relationship between forces (in Newton) in the active vs. passive fingers during a set of isolated finger movements. Higher numbers correlate with better finger-joint individuation, thus better dexterity.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Individuation Index at 3-months post-intervention
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 3-months post-intervention
primary_outcome.description: The relationship between forces (in Newton) in the active vs. passive fingers during a set of isolated finger movements. Higher numbers correlate with better finger-joint individuation, thus better dexterity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Box and Blocks Score test at the immediate post-intervention time
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-3 days post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The number of blocks transferred from one chamber to the other side within a minute. A higher number of blocks correlates with higher motor function.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Box and Blocks Score test at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The number of blocks transferred from one chamber to the other side within a minute. A higher number of blocks correlates with higher motor function.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Box and Blocks Score test at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The number of blocks transferred from one chamber to the other side within a minute. A higher number of blocks correlates with higher motor function.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Jebsen Taylor Hand Function Test (JTHF) Score at the immediate post-intervention time
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-3 days post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The time of performance of different tasks, mimicking the activity of daily living, is measured. Higher values correlate with decreased motor control.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Jebsen Taylor Hand Function Test (JTHF) Score at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The time of performance of different tasks, mimicking the activity of daily living, is measured. Higher values correlate with decreased motor control.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Jebsen Taylor Hand Function Test (JTHF) Score at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The time of performance of different tasks, mimicking the activity of daily living, is measured. Higher values correlate with better motor control.

secondary_outcome.measure: Arm Research Action Test (ARAT) Score at the immediate post-intervention time
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-3 days post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Time and quality of performance of 19 items mimicking activity of daily living, are measured. Tange: 0 - 57. Higher values correlate with better motor control.

secondary_outcome.measure: Arm Research Action Test (ARAT) Score at at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Time and quality of performance of 19 items mimicking activity of daily living, are measured. Range: 0 - 57. Higher values correlate with better motor control.

secondary_outcome.measure: Arm Research Action Test (ARAT) Score at at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Time and quality of performance of 19 items mimicking activity of daily living, are measured. Range: 0 - 57. Higher values correlate with better motor control.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in M1 MEP (motor evoked potentials) amplitude at immediate post-intervention time
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-3 days post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Stimulation of the ipsilesional M1 will be done using a 70-mm-diameter figure-of-eight coil connected to TMS to elicit motor-evoked potential (MEP) of the first dorsal interosseous (FDI) muscle of the right hand, recorded with an EMG electrode. The peak-to-peak time will be computed off-line using MATLAB software. Higher MEP amplitudes correlate with higher cortico-spinal integrity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in M1 MEP (motor evoked potentials) amplitude at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Stimulation of the ipsilesional M1 will be done using a 70-mm-diameter figure-of-eight coil connected to TMS to elicit motor-evoked potential (MEP) of the first dorsal interosseous (FDI) muscle of the right hand, recorded with an EMG electrode. The peak-to-peak time will be computed off-line using MATLAB software. Higher MEP amplitudes correlate with higher cortico-spinal integrity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in MEP (motor evoked potentials) amplitude at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Stimulation of the ipsilesional M1 will be done using a 70-mm-diameter figure-of-eight coil connected to TMS to elicit motor-evoked potential (MEP) of the first dorsal interosseous (FDI) muscle of the right hand, recorded with an EMG electrode. The peak-to-peak time will be computed off-line using MATLAB software. Higher MEP amplitudes correlate with higher cortico-spinal integrity.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in extent of SICI (short-interval cortical inhibition) at the immediate post-intervention time
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-3 days post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Single test pulses, conditioning pulses (five of each) and paired pulses (five pairs) at an inter-stimuli-interval (ISI) of 2 ms will be delivered to the motor cortex of both hemispheres. The intensity of the conditioning stimulus will be set at 80% of the subject's resting motor threshold (MT). The intensity of the test pulse will be 110% of the resting MT. The SICI will be measured as the reduction in conditioned MEPs relative to baseline MEPs. Higher SICI correlates with increased inhibitory activity of the motor cortex.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in extent of SICI (short-interval cortical inhibition) at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 1-month post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Single test pulses, conditioning pulses (five of each) and paired pulses (five pairs) at an inter-stimuli-interval (ISI) of 2 ms will be delivered to the motor cortex of both hemispheres. The intensity of the conditioning stimulus will be set at 80% of the subject's resting motor threshold (MT). The intensity of the test pulse will be 110% of the resting MT. The SICI will be measured as the reduction in conditioned MEPs relative to baseline MEPs. Higher SICI correlates with increased inhibitory activity of the motor cortex.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in extent of SICI (short-interval cortical inhibition) at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline Score at 3-months post-intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Single test pulses, conditioning pulses (five of each) and paired pulses (five pairs) at an inter-stimuli-interval (ISI) of 2 ms will be delivered to the motor cortex of both hemispheres. The intensity of the conditioning stimulus will be set at 80% of the subject's resting motor threshold (MT). The intensity of the test pulse will be 110% of the resting MT. The SICI will be measured as the reduction in conditioned MEPs relative to baseline MEPs. Higher SICI correlates with increased inhibitory activity of the motor cortex.

arm_group.description: The patient hand will be restrained to a robotic arm AMADEO(TM) which enables the measurement and manipulation of forces at each finger individually. After appropriate calibration, the force measurements obtained from the robot will be used to move a cursor on the screen. The patient will be rewarded visually and auditory when a higher degree of finger individuation will be measured. Specifically, when the applied force of the instructed fingers hit the predefined force target and at the same, the force in the non-instructed fingers stay as low as possible

The patient hand will be restrained to a robotic arm AMADEO(TM) which enables the measurement and manipulation of forces at each finger individually. After appropriate calibration, the force measurements obtained from the robot will be used to move a cursor on the screen. The patient will be rewarded in a way that is unrelated to the degree of individuation. In other words, a successful trial considered when the applied force of the instructed fingers hits the predefined force target regardless of the force exerted in the non-instructed fingers.

intervention.description: Interactive robot-mediated treatment aimed at increased individuation done repeatedly for at least1 hour per day for 2 weeks (5 training days a week).
Interactive robot-mediated treatment not aimed specifically at increased individuation done repeatedly for at least 1 hour per day for 2 weeks (5 training days per week)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- First symptomatic ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke
- Clinically evident upper-limb motor deficit
- Understand the study aim, is able to cooperate with the task for the specified time
- Clinically stable
Exclusion Criteria:
- Other neurological or psychiatric illness which affects upper-limb motor function
- An orthopedic or rheumatologic disease that affects the ability to undergo a robotic hand therapy.
- Sensory problems that prevent the patient from reporting pain during the robotic hand therapy
- Skin breakdown or wounds located in places where the hand contacts the robot.
- Patients with C/I to TMS (history of seizures, the existence of cardiac pacer, VP shunt, spinal stimulator or any other hardware that may malfunction at the presence of strong magnetic fields) will no undergo TMS but may participate in the study
- Participation in another interventional study for upper limb rehabilitation

responsible_party.investigator_title: Head of Research, Department of Neurological Rehabilitation
